text: My brother has been working there for the past 2 years. It's the only Superfund job going on in the country. But yes they are all working pretty much round the clock 7 days a week. They actually dug almost 300 feet down into the soil & at times hitting bedrock & still coming up with chemicals & toxins from close to 200 years ago. It's crazy how that stuff never disappears. But when that job is all complete the area & the canal will be clean enough to go kayaking & MAYBE even swimming. They are installing underground 12million gallon storage & overflow tanks, filtration systems which will clean up the canal & also stop the flooding problems in the area when it rains hard & also a beautiful park. It's gonna be great for the neighborhood. But like everything, some people always have to pay a price. And knock on wood it's not my brother or any other worker there in their futures breathing & being exposed to all that crap every day.

text: When my kids were young in the 90's I had a small wooden boat that I kept out at Dead Horse Bay, but I'd sail it to the canal, then motor all the way up to Union Street or Caroll street and moor it. We'd get in and out by climbing up the sides of the bridges. Their mother lived just up on President street, and I across fourth avenue, on Sackett. A lot of the waterfront was still almost lawless then. Nobody stopped you, or demanded permits or anything like that. People would live all Summer on the beaches out near Jamaica bay, unbothered by the law.  Even well into the 2000's we'd cart a big expedition kayak I had down there and paddle out to the bay. It was a magic time, because the water was no longer as hideously foul as it had been, but it was before the 1% bought it all for development. We could even get in and out of the boat directly onto Second Street, which was at the time just a bleak dead end where the working girls would bring their customers, and people would burn cars for the insurance money.  The canal was never naturally so foul--it became so because of the exit tunnel was broken for so many years.

text:
The Red Hook Grain Terminal is an abandoned grain elevator at the Gowanus Canal's mouth in Brooklyn's Red Hook neighborhood. 

Built in 1922, it is a 12-story concrete structure that is 429 feet long and has 54 silos, each standing 120 feet tall with 8-inch-thick walls to store combustible grain safely. 

Part of the New York State Canal System, it aimed to improve shipping along the Erie Canal. However, it was seen as a failure shortly after its September 1922 opening due to a decline in canal use and grain shipments.

text: The Loujaine, formerly known as the Abu Loujain, is a notable vessel that originally functioned as a cement and dry cargo ship. Today, it serves a new purpose as a floating storage hulk nestled in the picturesque Gowanus Canal, located in Brooklyn, New York. This ship was constructed in 1966 in Japan for Arabian Bulk Trade (ABT) and was later adapted for specialized cement handling. After being re-acquired by ABT, it was renamed and proudly flies the Panamanian flag, marking its transformation from an operational cargo carrier to a distinctive feature along the canal‚Äôs shoreline.

text:
In Pittsburgh, we have sewage treatment plants that treat the sewage before we dump the water back into the rivers leading into the Ohio River, which supplies water for Cincinnati, Ohio.
The sewage plants remove the slug (aka poop) from the sewage, then bakes (like baking a cake) and sends the slug to a landfill.  The remaining water mixture is purified to the point of being drinkable.  The water is sent to the Ohio River to provide water for Cincinnati. 
Side factoid: During the drought of 1988, Pittsburgh sent less water down to Cincinnati.   Pittsburgh dams held back water for Cincinnati. 
Dumping raw sewage into the canal is so uncivilized.   If New York asked Pittsburgh, we'd show you how to treat water, then you will be able to eat your clams.

text: I love your video, huge fan. But this one tickled my itch. I don't like this, to start with mankind took a natural environment and polluted it, terraformed it and transformed it into its current form today. Nature was devastated by this process but whilst there was a massive ecological impact life survived, adapted and evolved. That is where we are today. Now mankind is trying to 'restore' the previous natural state of the waterway. The process to achieve that is invasive sudden and severe chemical and physical alteration. This is as abrupt and destructive to the current natural state as was the original desecration. You are repeating the error. if you want this to transform back to its natural state. To heal. Stop! Stop all human intervention and activity. Let nature reclaim and rehabilitate in her own way. Anything else is just furthering the original thinking and destruction, for the sake of what 'looks good' to people. When are we going to stop destroying our environment whilst all along thinking we know best and that we are good? There is no greater evil than this.

text: I was born and raised on Baltic & Bond - just down the block from the "Boutique Hotel" she mentions. One block from the Gowanus Canal, and I can't even describe the deep, slimy green sludge that they call water. The smell during half the year - mostly late Spring and Summer. My mother, 3 sisters, uncle and his wife, all died from cancer. All between the ages of mid 40's to late 50's - no one made it past 60, mostly Leukemia and lung, organ cancers. Everyone was in good to very good health at time of diagnosis. Gentrifiers and Hipsters maybe have an immunity, who knows. The Gowanus Canal was definitely the common denominator for my family though.
